title: Acute Lateral Ankle Sprain in a Recreational Tennis Player
clinical_history: James is a 34-year-old recreational tennis player who sustained an injury to his right ankle during a doubles match three days ago. While chasing a wide ball, he landed awkwardly on the outside of his foot and immediately felt a sharp pain along the outer aspect of his right ankle. He was unable to continue playing and noted swelling developing rapidly within the hour. He has been able to weight-bear with significant discomfort but walks with an obvious limp. James reports that the ankle feels unstable, especially when negotiating stairs or uneven ground. He did not hear a pop but experienced moderate bruising by the following day. He denies any previous major ankle injuries.

nprs.affected_area: mild diffuse discomfort over dorsum of foot (secondary soft tissue swelling)

aggrevating_factors: Weight-bearing, walking (especially on uneven surfaces), descending stairs, attempting lateral movements, and especially inversion or twisting motions of the foot.
picture: [insert image highlighting the lateral aspect of the right ankle, marked swelling, ecchymosis]
easing_factors: Rest, elevation, ice application, compression bandage, and partial off-loading using crutches. Reports marginal relief with over-the-counter pain medication.
past_history: No prior history of significant ankle injuries. Occasional minor ankle discomfort after long tennis sessions, but nothing requiring medical attention.
medical_history: Generally healthy, no chronic medical conditions. Occasional mild seasonal allergies.
medications: Ibuprofen 400 mg as needed (1-2 times per day since injury), no regular medications.
personal_history: Works as a software engineer, lives with partner, active lifestyle including regular tennis and cycling. No tobacco use, moderate alcohol consumption socially.
imaging: No imaging performed to date; Ottawa Ankle Rules negative for fracture.
